thread.title: Potash Said to View K+S 50 Euro Valuation as Too High
thread.title_full: Potash Said to View K+S 50 Euro Valuation as Too High - Bloomberg Business

author: Danielle Bochove
title: Potash Said to View K+S 50 Euro Valuation as Too High
text:
K+S AG’s suggestion that it’s worth at least 50 euros a share in a takeover bid by Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan Inc. is unwarranted, according to people familiar with the Canadian fertilizer maker.
A bid at that price would be almost double K+S’s average price of 26 euros in the 12 months before the takeover talks became public, according to one of the people familiar with Potash Corp., who asked not to be identified because the discussions are private.
K+S rejected the 7.8 billion-euro ($8.7 billion) proposed bid from Saskatoon, Saskatchewan-based Potash Corp., saying that 41 euros a share was too low. The bid doesn’t reflect the rising value of K+S’s Legacy potash project in Canada, Chief Executive Officer Norbert Steiner said Thursday, indicating that an offer of at least 50 euros a share would be more appropriate.
Randy Burton, a spokesman for Potash Corp., declined to comment, as did Kassel, Germany-based K+S, beyond their statements.
K+S rose 4.4 percent to 38.67 euros Friday in Frankfurt, giving it a market value of 7.4 billion euros. Potash Corp. rose 0.67 percent to C$39.14 at 3:31 p.m. in Toronto.
Legacy is scheduled to start production by the end of next year and reach 2 million metric tons of capacity from 2017 onward. Its book value is about 11 euros per share, Steiner said Thursday. Taking into account future earnings from the mine, he said it’s worth as much as 21 euros a share.
K+S Shorts K+S is one of the most shorted stocks in Germany’s benchmark DAX Index, indicating a lack of investor confidence in the company, one of the people familiar with Potash said. At one point in May, short bets accounted for almost a fifth of outstanding shares, according to Markit data. In a short trade, investors bet the shares will decline, allowing them to buy the stock at a lower price.
A bid of 42.50 euros would result in an 80 percent probability that a deal gets done, according to a note Wednesday from John Klein, an analyst at Berenberg Equity Research.
